About Us Foolanthropy Fool.com Site Help Media Inquiries Contact Us Fool Podcasts Motley Fool Money Marketfoolery Industry Focus Motley Fool Answers Rule Breaker Investing Social Media + Facebook Twitter Discussion Boards CAPS - Stock Picking Community Login Search Search: Intel Corporation Lets Slip Details of 8th-Generation Core Processor More cores and slightly higher frequency than its predecessor. Ashraf Eassa (TMFChipFool) Mar 31, 2017 at 12:15PM In the second half of this year, processor giant Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) is expected to launch the first of its next-generation family of computer processors, marketed as eighth-generation Core. The first products to roll out are expected to be a family of chips currently code-named Kaby Lake Refresh, with products code-named Coffee Lake (for higher-end/higher-performance systems) following in the first half of 2018. Kaby Lake Refresh will be what Intel calls a "U" series processor. U-series chips tend to be Intel's highest-volume runners, targeting the bulk of the notebook personal computer market, as the slide below illustrates: Image source: AnandTech via WCCFTech. The Kaby Lake Refresh parts will come in what Intel refers to as a "4+2" configuration, meaning that it will have four processor cores paired with a graphics processor in a GT2 configuration (the "middle-of-the-road" graphics configuration from Intel). At Intel's recent Technology and Manufacturing Day, the company let slip some details about the upcoming Kaby Lake Refresh products. Let's take a look. Confirming core count, talking about frequency Intel executive Murthy Renduchintala showed the following slide: Image source: Intel. The purpose of this slide was to show investors that Intel is committed to improving its manufacturing technology performance and product designs to deliver better stuff each year. In the fine print found at the bottom of the slide, Intel provides details about the system configurations used to generate the claims with respect to chip performance. Intel's headline claim is that its eighth-generation Core processor family will deliver ">15% better performance" compared to its current-generation seventh-generation Core chips. Of course, the devil is in the details (or, in this case, the fine print). First, the fine print confirms that the chip will pack four cores, up from the two cores present on the company's current Kaby Lake-U series chips. Furthermore, Intel says that the upcoming Kaby Lake Refresh 4+2 chip will run at a maximum single-core turbo speed of 4GHz (+2.56% from the top Kaby Lake-U 2+2 part, though there is a 2+3e part currently available that offers 4GHz single-core turbo¬†). The combination of more cores and ever-so-slightly higher-frequency cores appears to allow Intel to deliver upon its claimed ">15%" performance improvement. It's worth noting, however, that Intel says that this performance estimate is a pre-silicon estimate (meaning that the number comes from simulations and not from measuring an actual chip) and that pre-silicon estimates have a "+/- 7% margin of error." Also, Intel explicitly says that these performance comparisons refer to the "top bin" (that is, the best chips) parts within each respective product family, so the gains elsewhere in the product stack might not be as large as those being claimed here. This is how Intel is leveraging 14-nanometer++ In a previous article, I went over Intel's claims about the 14-nanometer++ technology that will be used to manufacture the eighth-generation Core processor family. Intel claims that its 14-nanometer++ technology offers 26% better performance than its original 14-nanometer technology and so, by extension, it delivers roughly 12.5% better performance than its current 14-nanometer+ technology. What Intel seems to be doing is using these more powerful/power efficient transistors to boost the number of cores that it can cram into a low-power notebook processor. This is an interesting design choice, as Intel has spent many years focusing on trying to improve the per-core performance of its notebook and desktop processors (through a combination of frequency boosts and architectural gains) while keeping core counts stagnant. More cores should allow for dramatically higher performance in applications that can take advantage of multiple cores and should also serve to improve multi-tasking performance. It will be interesting to see if "more cores" ultimately proves to be a successful marketing point in the segment into which Intel will be selling Kaby Lake Refresh. Foolish takeaway At the end of the day, Intel wants to deliver new chips at a predictable annual cadence because Intel's own customers -- the companies that design and market personal computers -- really want new chips to build new systems around. What Intel is doing with its eighth-generation Core processors is leveraging improved manufacturing technology to be able to stuff more processor cores into a given thermal design power. This is a reasonable move given that the Kaby Lake Refresh/Coffee Lake were probably "late" additions to the company's product road map, but Intel can't rely on core count increases indefinitely. ¬† Ashraf Eassa owns shares of Intel. The Motley Fool recommends Intel. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy. Author Ashraf Eassa (TMFChipFool) Ashraf Eassa is a technology specialist with The Motley Fool. He writes mostly about technology stocks, but is especially interested in anything related to chips -- the semiconductor kind, that is. He can be reached on Twitter -- follow him there: Follow @tmfchipfool Article Info Mar 31, 2017 at 12:15PM Technology and Telecom Stocks Intel NASDAQ:INTC $36.07 up $0.32 (0.90%) Read More Why Long-Term Investors Should Prefer NVIDIA Over Intel How Intel Corporation's Execution Issues Have Helped Qualcomm, Inc. Will Intel Profit From Self-Driving Cars? KitGuru The KitGuru System Home News Reviews Gaming Lifestyle Mobile Professional Forum Home / Component / CPU / Intel‚Äôs enhanced 10nm tech to bring up to 40 percent performance boost over 14nm Intel‚Äôs enhanced 10nm tech to bring up to 40 percent performance boost over 14nm Matthew Wilson 14 hours ago CPU, Featured Tech News Earlier this week, Intel held its own ‚Äòtech day‚Äô during which it went over various technologies it is currently working on. One of the major points of the presentation was the upcoming 10nm process node, which Intel claims is a ‚Äòfull generation ahead‚Äô of¬†the 10nm technology competing chip makers are using, including Samsung, TSMC, Qualcomm and others. So what is so different about Intel‚Äôs 10nm tech compared to its rivals? Well for starters, it uses third-generation FinFET technology, but there is a bit more to it than that. One of the key focusses for Intel when it comes to 10nm is Hyper Scaling, which allows Intel to ‚Äúcontinue the benefits of Moore‚Äôs Law economics by delivering transistors that are smaller and have lower cost-per-transistor‚Äù. We can see Intel‚Äôs example of this in the graph below, which was published as part of the press materials for this event. With Intel‚Äôs 10nm node, the company claims it can deliver a 2.7x improvement in transistor density compared with its 14nm products. This is achieved due to the ‚Äòminimum gate pitch‚Äô shrinking from 70nm down to 54nm and the minimum metal pitch coming down from 52nm to 36nm. This enables a logic transistor density of 100.8 mega transistors per mm squared, which is estimated to be double that of competing 10nm chips. Aside from that, Intel‚Äôs jump from 14nm to 10nm will bring further improvements. The latest process node is said to deliver up to 25 percent better performance at a 45 percent lower power draw. An upcoming enhanced version of the 10nm process known as ‚Äô10++‚Äô will boost this performance benefit by an additional 15 percent, while reducing power draw by a further 30 percent. KitGuru Says: While other companies might already be out of the gate with 10nm products, it sounds like Intel‚Äôs own node is much more refined. If Intel‚Äôs 10nm CPUs can really deliver those performance advantages, coupled with reduced power draw, then this could end up being a big generational leap.¬† Share Facebook Twitter Google + Stumbleupon LinkedIn Pinterest Tags 10nm Intel news Previous Head down to MSI‚Äôs fan day and you could win some big prizes Check Also Mad Catz has ceased operations and filed for bankruptcy After a year or so of struggling financially, laying off staff and even getting delisted ‚Ä¶ CNFUZD Guys, april fools is only tomorrow, and no one is falling for the 40% performance increase joke anymore, anyway. It stopped being funny long ago üòõ Alex Ray its easy though, they release the CPU they‚Äôve kept in storage for years since AMD has been garbage until recently. plus, they add the secret sauce, half way decent thermal paste under the lid. CNFUZD Remember, coffee lake (end of this year or some such) is still 14nm, so this 10nm is not something we‚Äôll see for at least another year if not more. If they want to stop AMD from taking back market share, they better bring the secret sauce and all that jazz with coffee lake, not in another 12-16 months, by then the damage is done. Troy Smith its actually today if you live near the dateline RODDYGINGER Blowing smoke üòõ Polls Which CPU air cooler next? Antec Arctic be quiet! They now have a $39.00 price target on the stock. 2/10/2017 ‚Äì Intel had its ‚Äúbuy‚Äù rating reaffirmed by analysts at Needham & Company LLC. They wrote, ‚ÄúWe attended INTC‚Äôs Analyst Day at its Santa Clara Campus. The presentation was upbeat and management walked through its 2016 highlights, reiterated its 2017 financial targets and provided an outlook on its shift from a PC centric company to one that powers the cloud and connected devices. INTC is focusing on the performance segment of CCG to counteract a continuing decline in PCs. Management reiterated its 2017 DCG revenue outlook, but noted segment OM will take a ~5% over the next several years. INTC remains a step ahead of the competition in memory and storage with its investments in 3D NAND and Optane technology. Its IoT unit is focused on high growth areas, including ADAS.‚Äù‚Äù 2/10/2017 ‚Äì Intel had its ‚Äúoverweight‚Äù rating reaffirmed by analysts at Pacific Crest. They now have a $43.00 price target on the stock. 2/9/2017 ‚Äì Intel was downgraded by analysts at Vetr from a ‚Äústrong-buy‚Äù rating to a ‚Äúbuy‚Äù rating. They now have a $44.00 price target on the stock. 1/31/2017 ‚Äì Intel had its ‚Äúbuy‚Äù rating reaffirmed by analysts at Canaccord Genuity. They now have a $43.00 price target on the stock. 1/30/2017 ‚Äì Intel had its ‚Äúpositive‚Äù rating reaffirmed by analysts at Susquehanna Bancshares Inc. 1/30/2017 ‚Äì Intel had its ‚Äúhold‚Äù rating reaffirmed by analysts at SunTrust Banks, Inc.. 1/30/2017 ‚Äì Intel had its ‚Äúunderperform‚Äù rating reaffirmed by analysts at Raymond James Financial, Inc.. Shares of Intel Co. (NASDAQ:INTC) traded up 0.9972% during midday trading on Friday, reaching $36.1065. 7,100,452 shares of the company‚Äôs stock traded hands. Intel Co. has a 12 month low of $29.50 and a 12 month high of $38.45. The stock has a 50 day moving average of $35.72 and a 200-day moving average of $36.10. The stock has a market cap of $170.71 billion, a P/E ratio of 17.0314 and a beta of 1.03. Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) last announced its earnings results on Thursday, January 26th. The chip maker reported $0.79 earnings per share for the quarter, topping analysts‚Äô consensus estimates of $0.75 by $0.04. Intel had a net margin of 17.37% and a return on equity of 20.95%. The business earned $16.40 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $15.75 billion. During the same quarter last year, the firm earned $0.74 earnings per share. Intel‚Äôs quarterly revenue was up 10.1% on a year-over-year basis. On average, equities research analysts forecast that Intel Co. will post $2.80 EPS for the current fiscal year. The company also recently announced a quarterly dividend, which will be paid on Thursday, June 1st. Investors of record on Sunday, May 7th will be paid a dividend of $0.2725 per share. This represents a $1.09 dividend on an annualized basis and a yield of 3.05%. The ex-dividend date is Wednesday, May 3rd. This is an increase from Intel‚Äôs previous quarterly dividend of $0.26. Intel‚Äôs dividend payout ratio (DPR) is currently 49.29%. In related news, CEO Brian M. Krzanich sold 72,172 shares of Intel stock in a transaction on Monday, March 13th. The shares were sold at an average price of $35.21, for a total transaction of $2,541,176.12. Following the completion of the transaction, the chief executive officer now owns 549,091 shares of the company‚Äôs stock, valued at $19,333,494.11. The sale was disclosed in a legal filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission, which is available through this link. Also, EVP Stacy J. Smith sold 29,497 shares of Intel stock in a transaction on Friday, January 20th. The stock was sold at an average price of $36.76, for a total transaction of $1,084,309.72. Following the transaction, the executive vice president now directly owns 244,734 shares of the company‚Äôs stock, valued at approximately $8,996,421.84. The disclosure for this sale can be found here. Insiders have sold 273,023 shares of company stock valued at $9,898,612 in the last three months. 0.09% of the stock is owned by insiders. Intel Corporation is engaged in designing and manufacturing products and technologies, such as the cloud. The Company‚Äôs segments are Client Computing Group (CCG), Data Center Group (DCG), Internet of Things Group (IOTG), Non-Volatile Memory Solutions Group (NSG), Intel Security Group (ISecG), Programmable Solutions Group (PSG), All Other and New Technology Group (NTG). Email a friend To Use commas to separate multiple email addresses From 
		     Privacy Policy Thank you Your message has been sent. Sorry There was an error emailing this page. By Ian Paul Contributor, PCWorld | Mar 31, 2017 8:47 AM PT Credit: Intel More like this Intel's Optane: What users can expect in PCs and when it will ship Intel claims storage speed record with first large-capacity Optane SSD Intel's silence on Optane SSDs raises questions about launch and focus Video Let's Play Thimbleweed Park Intel‚Äôs revolutionary new non-volatile Optane Memory wants to make hard drives as fast as SSDs, but apparently not if you bought a PC on the cheap. The super-fast Optane Memory M.2 drives announced Monday not only require a Kaby Lake processor, but a Core one at that, as first spotted by¬†The Tech Report. According to Intel‚Äôs ARK database and Optane website, Kaby Lake-based Celeron and Pentium processors aren‚Äôt supported.¬† That‚Äôs puzzling because these new Optane Memory drives target mainstream PCs rather than enthusiast systems, supercharging the performance of traditional hard drive.¬†With an Optane M.2 drive installed, Intel promises speeds close to that of an SSD in some scenarios. The Optane Memory does this by caching your regular tasks, such as launching a particular program or game. The launch time then gets faster with each successive operation. It‚Äôs an interesting idea, and one that appeared easy to implement in Intel-controlled tests we performed at Optane‚Äôs launch event. But if this first round of Optane Memory is aimed at speeding up non-enthusiast PCs, why not support Celeron and Pentium? Non-enthusiasts often buy cheaper PCs that are likely to be running these lower grade processors (and traditional hard drives) rather than the more expensive Core CPUs. Nobody's reviewed these Optane cache drives yet but this restriction seems likely to narrow their potential audience. Why this matters: While this first release of Optane Memory may not excite hardcore gaming enthusiasts, the future for the technology could still be bright. When Intel and Micron first announced 3D XPoint‚Äîthe technology that Optane products use‚Äîthe companies promised nothing short of a revolution. 3D XPoint could function as both volatile and non-volatile memory with 1,000 times the performance and endurance of NAND-based SSDs, they claimed. This first effort for consumer-grade Optane gear doesn‚Äôt come close to that. But with Optane SSDs for servers rolling out in 2017, who knows what the future will bring? The idea of a full-blown, standalone Optane SSD is still tantalizing indeed. To comment on this article and other PCWorld content, visit our Facebook page or our Twitter feed. Related: PCs Components Processors Intel Ian is an independent writer based in Israel who has never met a tech subject he didn't like. He primarily covers Windows, PC and gaming hardware, video and music streaming services, social networks, and browsers. When he's not covering the news he's working on how-to tips for PC users, or tuning his eGPU setup. - Advertisement - - Advertisement - Site Contents Directory Sections Support OpEdNews Ad Rates Sign-in/Submit Refresh ¬† 1 2 4 1 (8 Shares) ¬† (# of views) ¬† 11 comments OpEdNews Op Eds 3/31/2017 at 15:19:17 The Private Contractors Using Vault 7 Tools for US Gov: Testimony Shows US Intel Needs a Ground-Up Rebuild Part 1 By George Eliason ¬† ¬†¬†¬† ¬†¬†¬† Permalink ¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† (Page 1 of 4 pages) Related Topic(s): Hackers; Intelligence; Intelligence Agencies; Websites, Add Tags Add to My Group(s) 4¬†¬† 3¬†¬† 2¬†¬† View Ratings | Rate It opednews.com Headlined to H2 3/31/17 Become a Fan ¬†¬†(53 fans) Senate expert #1 used to build websites. No Creds in Intel (Image by George Eliason) ¬†¬†Permission ¬†¬†Details ¬†¬†DMCA - Advertisement - The Vault 7 expose' by WikiLeaks neglected to mention the most important part of the disclosure. Sure, the CIA has all these tools available. Yes, they are used on the public. The important part is; it's not the CIA that's using them. That's the part that needs to frighten you. The CIA, by the definition of its mission, cannot use the tools in Vault 7, and definitely not on Americans. All the tools are unclassified, open-source, and can be used by anyone. It makes them not exactly usable for secret agent work. That's what makes it impossible for them to use Vault 7 tools directly. Because of the possible exposure for the agency, use of the tools was farmed out. - Advertisement - Instead, they are there for subcontractors to use. Are you worried about your TV watching you? Has your car developed the habit of starting itself in the morning? If these tools were solely in the hands of a US agency, you would be much safer. The agencies have limits on what they can do and agencies have oversight providing protections. Instead, intelligence and counterterrorism tools are in the hands of people that make most of their money pushing political agendas forward. And there is no oversight for what they are doing with the tools. In March 2015 , I started writing about private NSA guns for hire. These hired guns work in the revolving door between government Intel and counterterrorism and private intel and counterterrorism. What it showed was the same people that worked for US agencies and trained them were using the same tools and methods on Americans that they used for terrorist hunting. And they brag about it in social media. - Advertisement - The same people that take counterterrorism measures against Al Qaeda, are free to use those tools on you. According to CNN, Aaron Weisburd models his methods on the no-holds-barred Al Qaeda model. From CBS News -"sources close to U.S. intelligence as saying that "hackers knocked out Al Qaeda's online means of communication, thus preventing them from posting anything to commemorate 911 anniversary." The paper also said Western intelligence suspects two hackers were responsible: Aaron Weisburd from Internet Haganah and Rusty Shackleford from the web group My Pet Jawa." According to Sputnik News "As much as 80 percent of the US National Security Agency's (NSA) budget is privatized, demonstrating the merger between Washington and corporate organizations, WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange said Tuesday." This means that up to 80% of that budget is going to people in the private sector that are also working on other agendas, including their own. That's why we see more headlines like "NSA staff used spy tools on spouses, exlovers:watchdog." or "The Crazy Emails That Took Down NSA Spook John Schindler." Both articles show contractors use Vault 7 tools for their own domestic spying or revenge. In May 2015, the Nation published an article that is a must read to grasp how dangerous this has become. I've written intensively on how these tools are used to create news and policy from a ground and company level for NGO's and lobbyists. This article ratchets it up by looking at the policy makers and former agency heads that go into the private Intel and policy crafting business for hire. According to The Nation "These are the people--often referred to as "intelligence professionals"--who do the actual analytical and targeting work of the NSA and other agencies in America's secret government. Over the last 15 years, thousands of former high-ranking intelligence officials and operatives have left their government posts and taken up senior positions at military contractors, consultancies, law firms, and private-equity firms. In their new jobs, they replicate what they did in government--often for the same agencies they left. But this time, their mission is strictly for-profit." What does this have to do with overhauling the ODNI and 17 Intel agencies? Everything. From oversight to policy, the level of non-partisan professionalism needed to conduct unbiased intelligence work is no longer there. The Vault 7 leak could well be an inside attempt to address these issues. - Advertisement - "In the intelligence community in the United States, there are certain disgruntled individuals [concerned] about the way operations are being run, and it's obvious that material has come out that was felt by some of these individuals needed to be discussed," Kampmark explained." The ODNI and its agencies descent into shambles have been three presidencies in the making. Why a shambles? When intelligence is based on political agendas, rumor, or speculation instead of facts, it's in trouble. All of it was done in the name of getting faster intelligence and making actionable Intel available to members of Congress that had no business getting involved with classified, need to know basis intelligence. Submitted on Saturday, Apr 1, 2017 at 6:02:10 AM ¬†¬†¬†¬†(1+) ¬† David William Pear Senior Editor (Member since Nov 29, 2014), 32 fans, 38 articles, 150 quicklinks, 2003 comments, 1 diaries ¬†¬† In days of old, privateers were know as pirates and mercenaries. Governments paid them and gave them a license known as a letter of marque to murder, pillage and rape enemies of the state. In the last few decades, with the binge of privatization of government functions, the pirate industry has been booming. From Blackwater to Booz Allen Hamilton, privateers are running amok doing the dirty work of governments that would be illegal if the government itself did it. Modern pirates work hand in glove with the government, corporations and oligarchs. With a wink, a nod, and a multimillion dollar contract modern pirates can literally get away with murder and they will not be reported, investigated and prosecuted. Anyone who becomes an enemy of the state should be worried. That especially means political dissidents, activists, protesters and political mavericks. Google, Apple and Comcast are watching you. They are doing it for marketing reasons and to squeal on you to the deep state for big bucks. With plenty of information about you from technology, and not too much imagination anyone can be dragged from their home by the law, jailed, prosecuted and imprisoned by creatively connecting the dots to make anyone look like a subversive, terrorist and a danger to the "domestic tranquility", as mentioned in the preamble to the US Constitution. That goes double for politicians who cross the deep state. Honey traps, charges of corruption and being a Russian spy are not coincidences for troublemakers. I don't believe in coincidences anymore, whether it is Antony Weiner, Eliot Spitzer, Gary Webb, Chelsea Manning, Edward Snowden, Julian Assange, David Petraeus, Donald Trump, Devin Nunes, or YOU. Submitted on Saturday, Apr 1, 2017 at 4:09:35 AM ¬†¬†¬†¬†(3+) ¬† George Eliason (Member since Jan 10, 2011), 53 fans, 92 articles, 3 quicklinks, 668 comments, 2 diaries Reply to David William Pear: ¬†¬† Privateers are the only appropriate analogy. Another side of it offline is taking the information and getting people fired by naming them security threats to the state and threatening the business people work for. These operators threaten the ISPs that carry your service. Computing Mobile Internet Gaming Electronics Extreme Deep Dives Deals About ExtremeTech ET Forums Contact ExtremeTech Terms of Use Privacy Policy Ziff Davis Home Computing Intel claims three-year advantage on 10nm, wants to redefine process nodes Intel claims three-year advantage on 10nm, wants to redefine process nodes By Joel Hruska on March 31, 2017 at 9:27 am Comment Intel had a tech day this week to discuss the future of its own 14nm and 10nm chips, and it laid out some impressive claims in the process. It also laid out what it believes is a better metric for calculating process nodes in the future, though we suspect TSMC, Samsung, and GloFo may all disagree. Intel‚Äôs presentation focused mainly on two related topics: The strength and characteristics of its 10nm node, and its proposal for a new (or rather, a return to an old) method of calculating process node scaling. Intel drives ‚Äúhyperscaling‚Äù at the 10nm node Intel is claiming that its 10nm node will deliver a 2.7x improvement in transistor density compared with its 14nm products. That‚Äôs a significant jump over its 14nm products, and it‚Äôs not just the result of the improvements to various semiconductor manufacturing metrics. Intel has improved its 10nm scaling compared with 14nm through the use of two specific new technologies ‚Äî single dummy gate, and contact-over-active-gate. Typically, logic cells use a pair of what are called ‚Äúdummy gates‚Äù to isolate each cell from its neighbors. Intel has found a method of using just one dummy gate instead of using a pair of them, and has managed to recover significant space savings as a result. Each gate has multiple contacts that connect to the metal layers within a CPU. Typically, these contacts are offset from the gate. At 10nm, Intel is moving the contact to directly under the gate, which frees up additional transistor space. All of these advantages combined is why Intel is claiming such significant improvements compared with 14nm. The slides below includes visualizations of these improvements and how they collectively improve Intel‚Äôs 10nm process node. All slides can be clicked on to expand them in a new window. The general thrust of Intel‚Äôs argument is that these new technologies will give it a significant lead over its rivals and competitors in the foundry space. Intel vs. everyone at the 10nm node One major point of Intel‚Äôs presentation is actually something we‚Äôve discussed before: When TSMC, Samsung, GlobalFoundries and Intel talk about 14nm, the process nodes they discuss are not identical. Each foundry has implemented different feature sizes and each of their nodes (16nm/12nm for TSMC, 14nm for Samsung and GF) has its own distinct characteristics. To some extent, the modern definition of a node has become ‚ÄúThe bucket of technologies we periodically dump in to improve some aspects of transistor density, power consumption, and performance enough to justify moving to a new number.‚Äù The problem, at least for Intel, is that when a company like Samsung announces 10nm production, that‚Äôs actually roughly equivalent to Intel‚Äôs 14nm, which debuted in 2014. To get around this issue, Intel has described a method for calculating process node size that would weight certain factors differently than they are weighted today. Intel‚Äôs Process Architecture and Integration Director, Mark Bohr, described the formula in an editorial published by Intel: One simple metric is gate pitch (gate width plus spacing between transistor gates) multiplied by minimum metal pitch (interconnect line width plus spacing between lines), but this doesn‚Äôt incorporate logic cell design, which affects the true transistor density. Another metric, gate pitch multiplied by logic cell height, is a step in the right direction with regard to this deficiency. But neither of these takes into account some second order design rules‚Ä¶ At the other extreme, simply taking the total transistor count of a chip and dividing by its area is not meaningful because of the large number of design decisions that can affect it ‚Äì factors such as cache sizes and performance targets can cause great variations in this value. It‚Äôs time to resurrect a metric that was used in the past but fell out of favor several nodes ago. It is based on the transistor density of standard logic cells and includes weighting factors that account for typical designs. While there is a large variety of standard cells in any library, we can take one ubiquitous, very simple one ‚Äì a 2-input NAND cell (4 transistors) ‚Äì and one that is more complex but also very common: a scan flip flop (SFF). This leads to a previously accepted formula for transistor density: (The weightings 0.6 and 0.4 reflect the ratio of very small and very large cells in typical designs.) Every chip maker, when referring to a process node, should disclose its logic transistor density in units of MTr/mm2 (millions of transistors per square millimeter) as measured by this simple formula. Reverse engineering firms can readily verify the data. Measuring process node metrics in this fashion would give Intel an obvious advantage over all of its rivals. As such, it‚Äôs hard to imagine they‚Äôll ever endorse it. Whether its TSMC with a new ‚Äú12nm‚Äù node or potential future gaps between the various pure-play foundries at 7nm, nobody but Intel will substantially benefit from measuring process nodes differently, even if Intel‚Äôs method is more accurate. The¬†slides below steps through some of Intel‚Äôs transistor density comparisons against its competitors‚Äô nodes, as well as how it compares against them on specific metrics and how large it expects the gaps to be at 10nm. We can‚Äôt speak to the accuracy of Intel‚Äôs projections for its competitors at 10nm, but the company‚Äôs general projection matches what we‚Äôve seen at the 14nm node. With Intel taking on more foundry customers (or trying to), it doubtlessly sees this as a potential barrier to those efforts. What‚Äôs the point of calling a node ‚Äú10nm‚Äù (from Intel‚Äôs perspective) if that artificially inflates the value of what your competitors‚Äô are selling and diminishes your own value? The other interesting question is how much these advantages will practically matter going forward. When Intel intended to break into the tablet and smartphone markets to compete directly against ARM, it had an obvious rationale for comparing its own performance against Samsung, GlobalFoundries, and TSMC. Today, Intel and the pure-play foundries once again move in different circles ‚Äî but that could change in the future if Intel can land some significant foundry deals. The other reason foundry die shrinks aren‚Äôt as interesting as they used to be is for the simple reason that they don‚Äôt deliver much in the way of improved performance any more, at least not outside specific market segments. Six years ago, the Core i5-2537M was a Sandy Bridge-era core clocked at 1.4GHz base / 2.3GHz Turbo with a TDP of 17W. Today, Intel‚Äôs Core i5-7300U is a 15W chip with a 2.6GHz base clock and a 3.5GHz Turbo. It‚Äôs TDP is 15W. Intel, in other words, improved the base clock by 1.86x and the boost clock by 1.52x all while trimming the TDP. But in the desktop space, performance gains have been rarer, overclocking headroom has shrunk, and frequency gains have been doled out very sparingly. Intel has absolutely made progress over this time, but not at anything like a quick pace. Again, that‚Äôs not the company‚Äôs fault ‚Äî it‚Äôs related, as we‚Äôve said before, more to the difficulties with scaling silicon than anything ‚Äî but with AMD surging back into the CPU fight, Intel may find itself under increased pressure to demonstrate that its 10nm hardware can do more than look impressively futuristic in a variety of graphs.¬† Intel‚Äôs full presentations are available for download, if you‚Äôd care to flip through them yourself. Tagged In intel samsung semiconductors TSMC 14nm GlobalFoundries transistors 20nm 10nm 22nm 7nm process¬†node Post a Comment Comment ExtremeTech Newsletter Subscribe Today to get the latest ExtremeTech news delivered right to your inbox. About Us Foolanthropy Fool.com Site Help Media Inquiries Contact Us Fool Podcasts Motley Fool Money Marketfoolery Industry Focus Motley Fool Answers Rule Breaker Investing Social Media + Facebook Twitter Discussion Boards CAPS - Stock Picking Community Login Search Search: Here's How Intel Corporation Could Refresh Server Chips in 2018 14-nanometer++ to the rescue. Ashraf Eassa (TMFChipFool) Mar 31, 2017 at 10:30AM In the middle of 2017, Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) is expected to launch its next-generation processor family targeted at the server market, based on its Skylake server architecture. These chips promise to deliver significant improvements in both processor performance and efficiency while also delivering a lot of new platform-level features as well. These new chips, per website ServeTheHome, will be manufactured using Intel's 14-nanometer+ manufacturing technology. This technology, Intel has said, delivers a 12% performance boost relative to the company's first-generation 14-nanometer technology that's used to manufacture its current generation Broadwell-based server processors. Image source: Intel. That process technology enhancement, coupled with the significant architectural/design improvements that Intel plans to bring with the new Skylake Server chips, should make for a compelling improvement to the chipmaker's data center processor product line. What's interesting, though, is that at the company's Technology and Manufacturing Day hosted on March 28, Intel executive Murthy Renduchintala said that the company intends to update all its product lines at an annual cadence. Presumably, this includes Intel's data center processor lineup. Here's how I expect Intel to refresh this product line next year. What comes after 14-nanometer+? At the Technology and Manufacturing Day, Intel said that it plans to go into production on a new variant of its 14-nanometer technology, known as 14-nanometer++, later this year. This technology will first be used to build the company's eighth-generation Core processors for personal computers later this year, and it promises to deliver roughly a 12.5% performance enhancement over the company's 14-nanometer+ technology. Image source: Intel. Since it is unlikely that Intel's 10-nanometer or 10-nanometer+ technologies will be in good enough shape to build enormous server processors next year -- and considering that Intel has publicly said that its 10-nanometer and 10-nanometer+ technologies will offer lower performance than its 14-nanometer++ technology -- Intel is more likely to update its server processor product line by migrating it to the 14-nanometer++ technology. Bigger, but better, chips Intel has said that the transistor gate pitch of its 14-nanometer++ technology is 84-nanometers, up quite a bit from the 70-nanometers of its 14-nanometer and 14-nanometer+ technologies. In a nutshell, this means that Intel not only won't see an area reduction in moving from 14-nanometer+ to 14-nanometer++, but it could see chip area grow somewhat. That said, data center customers aren't buying chip area, they're buying performance and power efficiency. Ideally for said customers, Intel would be able to offer the better-performing (and slightly larger) chips for the same prices as the prior-generation products; in that case, the slight chip size increase would be completely irrelevant to Intel's customers (though this could potentially mean slight margin erosion for Intel). However, even if the chip size increase drives up prices a smidgen -- perhaps commensurate with any cost structure increase Intel would incur from the larger chip sizes -- data center customers might not care too much if the performance increase is compelling enough. Better than nothing The bottom line is this: Even if Intel delivers "just" a manufacturing technology improvement to its data center product line in 2018 without any significant changes in the architecture, core count, and so on, then that's still better than delivering nothing at all. What will be interesting to see, then, is what Intel brings to this market in the 2019 time frame and beyond. Ashraf Eassa owns shares of Intel. The Motley Fool recommends Intel. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy. Author Ashraf Eassa (TMFChipFool) Ashraf Eassa is a technology specialist with The Motley Fool. He writes mostly about technology stocks, but is especially interested in anything related to chips -- the semiconductor kind, that is. He can be reached on Twitter -- follow him there: Follow @tmfchipfool Article Info Mar 31, 2017 at 10:30AM Technology and Telecom Stocks Intel NASDAQ:INTC $36.07 up $0.32 (0.90%) Read More Why Long-Term Investors Should Prefer NVIDIA Over Intel How Intel Corporation's Execution Issues Have Helped Qualcomm, Inc. Will Intel Profit From Self-Driving Cars? Paul McGeough Follow on Twitter 133 reading now Show comments facebook SHARE twitter TWEET email google-plus linkedin reddit More Washington: Dodgy email practice and 3am phone calls have become rites of passage at Foggy Bottom. Former secretary of state Hillary Clinton set both as tests of grit and leadership. Email practice contributed to her failed 2016 presidential bid; and in the heat of her failed run for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2008, she ran TV ads claiming she was better equipped than her rival Barack Obama to deal with crises that would erupt in the middle of the night. More videos Rex Tillerson strategy to defeat ISIS With US-backed Iraqi forces battling to retake Iraq's second-largest city from the Islamic State group, the United States called for other nations to step up efforts in the Middle East. Happily, Rex Tillerson, former ExxonMobil CEO and Donald Trump's Secretary of State, passed his early-hours test ‚Äì it happened in impoverished Yemen. But the jury is out on his emails. There is a tantalising probe into the extent to which ExxonMobil misled shareholders on the impact of their products on climate change that bubbles along in New York and which may, or may not, prove embarrassing for Tillerson. The Yemen business was a try-on by a Yemeni prime minister who, after three days of haggling in Sanaa, the Yemeni capital, had struck a big-ticket energy deal with the young Tillerson ‚Äì or so Tillerson believed. Related Content Rex Tillerson and James Mattis in charm offensive to reassure worried US allies Tillerson urges other countries to cough up more for war on IS An exhausted Tillerson had crashed, sleeping ahead of a 6am flight home to Texas. But his phone rang at close to 3am ‚Äì it was the PM, demanding an immediate reopening of the negotiations. Tillerson hauled himself back to the government bunker ‚Äì the Yemeni played hardball, Tillerson didn't blink. "The Prime Minister tried to retrade the deal and Rex just basically just said 'No,'" Politico magazine was told. And this, a Tillerson associate explained, was proof that "Rex can say 'No', and do so in a way that is not offensive and doesn't create unnecessary battles ‚Äì the government of Yemen wasn't going away and we needed to deal with it." Advertisement The gist of the email business is this ‚Äì ExxonMobil is accused of replicating the tactics of big tobacco, funding climate change deniers, despite knowing its energy products contributed to climate change, just as the tobacco giants covered up that their products were killing their customers. Responding to a demand for documents by New York State Attorney-General Eric Schneiderman, ExxonMobil reluctantly revealed the existence of a trove of Tillerson's emails, sent as CEO but under the alias "Wayne Tracker", which had been "lost" for reasons the company insists are innocent. Schneiderman is plugging away and ultimately ExxonMobil and Tillerson may be cleared, but for now the optics are a messy reminder of Clinton's obsessive and ill-judged need for secrecy in the saga of her emails. SHARE Share on Facebook SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.¬†Photo: Bloomberg Tillerson's transition from the corporate sphere to the world of diplomacy ‚Äì and the diplomacy of the world ‚Äì has Washington transfixed. It's early days and he does have strong defenders. But in switching from being his own master to serving Donald Trump, from being answerable to 2.5 million narrowly focused shareholders to being accountable to more than 300 million citizens of all views and opinions, Tillerson is widely criticised for failing to project himself and his issues; of being cowed by a bullyboy President and his inner circle; and of failing to grasp, or to be even mildly interested in, the survival essentials of bureaucratic and political life. SHARE Share on Facebook SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson in Beijing.¬†Photo: AP The new Secretary of State is cast as the hermit of Foggy Bottom, a cognomen the State Department takes from the DC quarter in which it is located. Some of Tillerson's senior management walked out even before his Senate confirmation and on arriving he showed more the door. The White House refuses to allow him to make his own senior appointments, and, something of a sacrilege in Washington, he shuns the media. "He's isolated and he's not using the leverage of his office," Ilan Goldenberg, of the Centre for a New American Security, told Fairfax Media. "He's fundamentally disconnected ‚Äì people at the State Department don't know what's happening on the seventh floor." SHARE Share on Facebook SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link A North Korean soldier taking a photograph while Rex Tillerson visits the border of South and North Korea.¬†Photo: AP If Tillerson is strangely absent from the brightly lit Washington stage, he is mentioned only obliquely in wonkish assessments of the Trump national security team, which, generally, focus on the role in government of Defence Secretary Jim Mattis, of National Security Adviser General H. R. McMaster and of Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly. As with other Washington portfolios, the self-styled "wrecking ball" Trump is disruptive when it comes to foreign policy. He'll happily take out his angst with the world on Twitter, thereby requiring his cabinet appointees to wind back positions more in keeping with the challenging credo of the Bannon-Miller axis, than they are with the more conservative, establishment thinking of the likes of Mattis, McMasters and Tillerson. SHARE Share on Facebook SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link Rex Tillerson with US President Donald Trump at a meeting with Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi.¬†Photo: AP In January, Team Trump hailed Tillerson's nomination, claiming it would "help reverse years of misguided foreign policies and actions that [had] weakened" the standing of the US in the world. But the new man is no carbon copy of his leader and neither is he as two-dimensional as depicted in some media profiles. While Trump was leaning towards lifting sanctions on Moscow, imposed after his annexation of Crimea, Tillerson told his Senate confirmation hearing that the West should be alarmed by Russian aggression; unlike Trump, he voiced strong support for the US commitment to NATO and he endorsed US arms for Ukraine, to help it to repel Russia's push into its territory. SHARE Share on Facebook SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link China's President Xi Jinping with Rex Tillerson in Beijing.¬†Photo: AP In Beijing earlier this month, Tillerson displayed more realpolitik than Trump belligerence in his dealing with Chinese officials ‚Äì to the point of using Chinese phraseology, which was read in the Chinese capital as his endorsement of the Chinese belief that Washington should embrace China's stand on the South China and East China Seas and Taiwan and on human rights in Tibet and Xinjiang. ExxonMobil is defending its record on climate change. But Tillerson can claim that it was on his watch as CEO that the energy behemoth embraced scientific arguments on greenhouse gas emissions and climate change ‚Äì which anchors him more in scientific reality than Trump. And philosophically, he's a global free trader ‚Äì again putting him at odds with the President. In a conference speech in 2007 he declared: "Energy made in America is not as important as energy simply made wherever it is most economic." As national president of the Boy Scouts in the US, it was through Tillerson's advocacy that the movement agreed to accept gay members. And he is a former director of the United Negro College Fund, a group that funds scholarships for black students and supports historically black colleges and universities in the US. Still, Steve Coll sees great irony in Tillerson's appointment. The author of Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power, Coll writes in The New Yorker: "Some of the Exxon executives I interviewed spoke about Washington with disdain, if not contempt. They regarded the State Department as generally unhelpful, a bureaucracy of liberal career diplomats who were biased against oil and incompetent when it came to sensitive and complex oil-deal negotiations. They managed Congress defensively, and as just one capital among many in the world, a place more likely to produce trouble for Exxon than benefits. "In nominating Tillerson, Trump is handing the State Department to a man who has worked his whole life running a parallel quasi-state, for the benefit of shareholders, fashioning relationships with foreign leaders that may or may not conform to the interests of the United States government." Tillerson is a unique appointment. His entire career has been in the service of ExxonMobil and he takes office having done neither government nor military service. But he knows his way around the world and he knows how to cut a deal ‚Äì though the manner of some have raised eyebrows. Trump did not go into specifics on the appointment, but some analysts have picked on the President's narrow focus on the intersection of foreign policy and US economic interest ‚Äì as borne out in Trump's "take the oil" claim on Iraq and his short-lived willingness to use Taiwan as a bargaining chit with Beijing. On one level, Tillerson is a novice. On another he's not. In running ExxonMobil, he presided over a global staff of 75,000 with operations in as many as 200 countries and constantly having to finesse deals with the likes of Vladimir Putin in Russia; Hugo Chavez in Venezuela, Idriss Deby in Chad and Ali Abdullah Saleh in Yemen. "Those early assignments where I worked internationally and the things I learned there have served me well ever since," Tillerson told an interviewer in 2007. It remains to be seen how he'll get along with Baghdad, given a 2011 oil development deal he cut with the Iraqi Kurds ‚Äì he left the central Iraqi government out and undercut Washington's support for a national deal under which Kurds, Shiites and Sunnis would benefit from the country's vast oil reserves. He became very close to Putin who awarded him Order of Friendship in 2013. Some analysts are troubled by Tillerson's settling-in at the State Department. They see no push-back against a White House takeover ‚Äì Trump wants to cut Tillerson's budget by about 30 per cent; Trump, his son-in-law Jared Kushner and strategist Stephen Bannon are seen to be running a parallel "State Department" from the White House; Tillerson is locked out on the appointment of envoys; and Trump has twice embarrassed Tillerson while he has been abroad ‚Äì blasting China via Twitter for not doing enough to ease the North Korea crisis while Tillerson was in Beijing; and crowing about how he'd be getting rid of "bad dudes" from the US while Tillerson was in Mexico City. Inside-the-beltway conspiracy theorists speculate that Bannon is calculatedly attempting to sideline the State Department, citing as proof the very public warning by now sacked National Security Adviser Mike Flynn that Iran was "on notice" not to attempt further missile tests, and the quashing of Tillerson's move to appoint former Bush official Elliott Abrams as his deputy. Tufts University's Professor Daniel Drezner is scathing. He told Fairfax Media: " It's possible [Tillerson] will learn the lie of the land and be competent, but there is zero evidence. Beyond Trump's [belated] adherence to the One China policy, I've seen nothing [Tillerson] has done that is constructive ... and he seems to be willfully alienating the State Department." Henry Kissinger, the grandee of Republican foreign policy, was diplomatic after meeting Tillerson. "The normal tendency when you come into that job is to increase your visibility and to show that you are present and in charge," he told The New York Times. "[But] he wanted to first inform himself of all the nuances. I was impressed by the confidence and self-assurance that he showed." Tillerson is seldom seen and not often heard ‚Äì he shuns public appearances; is absent from media coverage of Trump's meetings with foreign leaders; and is seemingly resigned to the White House making the final decision on who is to work at State and to Trump's plans to hack into his budget. Theories on his low-key arrival are many ‚Äì he wants to lock in key administration relationships before committing himself on policy; he's waiting for the dust to settle in the factional wars at the White House; and that at the end of the day, he's an energy CEO ‚Äì you cut a deal, you go home and you say as little as possible. Some foreign diplomats and former officials reject the intensity of media criticism of Tillerson, and particularly of his reluctance to have the press travel with him. Former senior Obama appointee and Asia policy expert Evan Medeiros told Politico: "that's Washington navel-gazing. That's not what the region is preoccupied with ... [The Chinese in particular] like to deal with people that are cool, careful, discreet ‚Äî but very credible interlocutors. And I think right now they see Tillerson like that." Explaining himself in a rare interview, Tillerson said: "I'm not a big media press access person. I personally don't need it ... When I have something important and useful to say, I know where everybody is and I know how to go out there and say it. "But if I don't because we're still formulating and we're still deciding what we're going to do, there is not going to be a lot to say." Suzanne Maloney, a former ExxonMobil staffer now at the Brookings Institution, rushed to Tillerson's defence on Twitter: "Oil folks know stuff: anyone who manages multibillion-dollar, multi-decade projects needs deep, nuanced understanding of political context ‚Ä¶ Tillerson rose to top of a company that prizes technical excellence, rock-solid financials, hard work and integrity. State could do a lot worse." But a worry, as expressed by Thomas Wright of the Brookings Institution, is though Trump may be getting boxed in on much of the foreign and national security agenda by the establishment sensibilities of Mattis, McMasters and Tillerson, at age 70 this President is not likely to change, because he feels vindicated by winning the election "after a lifetime of howling at the moon". So how will Trump respond when, inevitably, he gets the 3am call? Will his national security team get time to reel him in, or might they have conditioned him in time to be as measured as Americans need him to be when the balloon goes? What will be Tillerson's role in all that? Trump picked this Secretary of State on the recommendation of former defence secretary and CIA director Robert Gates ‚Äì a Bush appointee kept on by Obama. This is how Gates celebrated Tillerson's credentials in January, during the latter's Senate confirmation hearing: "Against a backdrop of having known, or worked with 12 secretaries of state, I believe Mr Tillerson is superbly qualified ... He is deeply knowledgeable about the international scene and geopolitics. And importantly, would be an informed and independent adviser to the President." Skip to content MilTech PR Distribution Menu HOME Add the press release Our team & Contact Posted on 31 March 2017 by Military News Why Intel Now Has a Huge Advantage in Self-Driving Cars Tech analysts will tell you that chip giant Intel Corporation (NASDAQ: INTC) is a mixed bag. On the one hand, it‚Äôs a big player in personal computers, which isn‚Äôt exactly a growth market . And it has been seen as lagging rivals in the emerging artificial-intelligence space. But it took a huge step into autonomous vehicles when it announced a $15.3 billion deal to acquire Mobileye N.V. (NYSE: MBLY) earlier this month. I think that makes it worth a closer look. Here‚Äôs why. Mobileye‚Äôs co-founder, Amnon Shashua, announcing a partnership with Intel and BMW last year. Image source: Mobileye N.V. Why Intel paid a fortune for Mobileye Intel is paying $15.3 billion for Mobileye, seemingly a huge price for a company that generated just over $358 million-with-an-m in revenue last year. Why? The key is that Mobileye is the closest thing to a pure play in self-driving vehicles, at least among public companies. Mobileye makes chips and software that process images and that are designed from the ground up to be used in cars. They‚Äôre already critical components of today‚Äôs advanced driver-assist systems, and they‚Äôll be critical to tomorrow‚Äôs self-driving vehicles as well. Put another way, Mobileye has proven technology that will have an important role in the autonomous vehicles of the near future. It also has something else, which might be just as valuable: Credibility with automakers. Mobileye‚Äôs current client list includes nearly all of the world‚Äôs automakers. That‚Äôs important because the auto industry can be a tough market for a technology company to crack. But Intel won‚Äôt have to crack it, because Mobileye has already done so. And rather than folding Mobileye into Intel, the chip giant plans to go the other way, keeping Mobileye‚Äôs sales force and management team intact while expanding its range of offerings to include Intel‚Äôs products. Mobileye opens up a huge new market for Intel So how big is the opportunity for Intel here? As Intel sees it, it‚Äôs huge. CEO Brian Krzanich thinks of self-driving cars as ‚Äûdata centers on wheels,‚Äù with good reason. The computer processing power that will be required in cars with the most basic Level 4 self-driving systems is roughly a hundred times the computing power in today‚Äôs most advanced cars, Krzanich said in a recent presentation. How Intel‚Äôs CEO sees the growth opportunity from self-driving cars. Image source: Intel Corporation. That‚Äôs a big opportunity for Intel to sell additional hardware to Mobileye‚Äôs established client list. How big? Krzanich thinks the total addressable market for vehicle systems will be over $20 billion a year by 2020, and could be $70 billion a year by 2030. On top of that, Krzanich sees a second, related opportunity in the actual data centers that will be needed to provide the ‚Äûcloud‚Äù for all of these interconnected self-driving cars. That won‚Äôt be a big new market soon, but it could be up around $40 billion a year by 2030. Whatever its other flaws, Intel is now in a prime position to grab a big piece of that. What Mobileye does for Intel as an investment These new autonomous-vehicle markets could represent substantial top-line growth for Intel. Consider that the chip giant generated $59.4 billion in revenue in 2016. If the markets materialize as Krzanich anticipates, and Intel can take even a third of them‚Ä¶then the $15.3 billion that Intel is paying for Mobileye might look like a bargain in time. As plenty of analysts have pointed out, Intel‚Äôs fundamentals today aren‚Äôt very exciting. Its forward price-to-earnings ratio is just over 12, with a forward dividend yield of 3.1% and a payout ratio of 49%. That‚Äôs all decent but not exceptional. What might be exceptional about Intel is that it‚Äôs buying itself a gateway to significant future growth. That‚Äôs worth a closer look. 10 stocks we like better than Intel When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip, it can pay to listen. After all, the newsletter they have run for over a decade, Motley Fool Stock Advisor , has tripled the market.* David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy right now‚Ä¶ and Intel wasn‚Äôt one of them! That‚Äôs right ‚Äî they think these 10 stocks are even better buys. Click here to learn about these picks! *Stock Advisor returns as of February 6, 2017 John Rosevear has no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool recommends Intel. The Motley Fool has a disclosure policy . The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc. Facebook Twitter Google + Email Print DEMS DARING TO MESS WITH TEXAS ‚Äì Flynn seeks immunity deal with Intel panels ‚Äì MODERATE DEMS ON TRUMP: ‚ÄòNOT GOING TO SUPPORT CRAZY‚Äô ‚Äì GOP infighting explodes 03/31/17 08:06 AM EDT By Heather Caygle (hcaygle@politico.com or @heatherscope) With an assist from Burgess Everett Story Continued Below TAKING BACK THE MAJORITY IN THREE EASY STEPS ‚Äî Senate Democrats face long-shot odds to taking back the majority in 2018. But the path to do it involves knocking out conservative firebrand Ted Cruz in Texas. Democratic Rep. Beto O‚ÄôRourke ‚Äî a 44-year-old former hard rock musician and internet entrepreneur who speaks fluent Spanish ‚Äî is hoping to do just that when he enters the race today. ‚ÄúTexas is how you win back the Senate,‚Äù O‚ÄôRourke said in an interview earlier this month. But it‚Äôs not that easy. Democrats are defending 25 seats, including 10 in states President Donald Trump carried. They would have to hold onto all of those seats and pick up three more held by the GOP‚ÄîArizona, Nevada and Texas are the best targets ‚Äîto take back the majority. ‚ÄòA suicide mission‚Äô: ‚ÄúI know Beto. And he‚Äôs a good guy. But I think this is a suicide mission,‚Äù said Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn, another Texan and a two-time chairman of the party‚Äôs Senate campaign arm. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt elected a Democrat statewide since ‚Ä¶ 1994.‚Äù If Democrats can legitimately put Texas in play ‚Äî still an if ‚Äî it could help propel voter turnout and be a boon for fundraising. ‚ÄúPeople want to win and they want to play offense. And Texas represents that,‚Äù O‚ÄôRourke said. Much more from Burgess and yours truly: http://politi.co/2oG1rUU ‚ÄòI‚ÄôM NOT GOING TO SUPPORT CRAZY‚Äô ‚Äî To score any major legislative wins in the House, Trump will need to convince either a wing of Freedom Caucus members or Democrats to join with Republicans. The president has attacked both groups on Twitter recently, just another example of behavior Democrats say gives them no incentive to offer the White House a helping hand anytime soon. Kind keeping it real: ‚ÄúI do come from a district that did flip to Trump this time but I don‚Äôt think they should be reading that as a slam dunk,‚Äù said Rep. Ron Kind, one of 12 Democrats sitting in Trump-won House seats. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to support crazy up here.‚Äù GOP Rep. Bruce Poliquin has tried to facilitate outreach between the White House and some moderate Democrats, with mixed success. ‚ÄúWill they attract one or two Democrats on whatever piece of garbage they want to offer? Maybe,‚Äù said New Dem Chairman Jim Himes, who is open to sitting down with Trump‚Äôs team. But early talk from the White House about corralling a few Democratic votes has to stop, Himes added. ‚ÄúThey better leave the ‚Äòpicking off‚Äô language behind and start talking about what we would need.‚Äù Much more from Kyle and yours truly: http://politi.co/2nRYzai FLYNN SEEKS IMMUNITY DEAL ‚Äî Former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn has made a pitch to the FBI and the House and Senate Intel Committees: He‚Äôs willing to be interviewed about Russia in exchange for immunity from prosecution. ‚ÄúHe has made the offer to the FBI and the House and Senate intelligence committees through his lawyer but has so far found no takers, the officials said,‚Äù reports the Wall Street Journal‚Äôs Shane Harris, Carol Lee and Julian Barnes. Flynn‚Äôs lawyer acknowledged the former Trump aide is seeking ‚Äúassurances against unfair prosecution‚Äù from the House and Senate panels. But a spokesman for the House Intel Committee on Thursday night said that the panel had yet to receive any such request from Flynn. Austin Wright, Josh Meyer and Martin Matishak with more: http://politi.co/2np2315 Limits to that request: ‚ÄúCongress has the power to grant only limited ‚Äòtestimonial‚Äô immunity, which means prosecutors cannot use witnesses‚Äô testimony against them in any prosecution. Ultimately, it is Justice‚Äôs decision whether to grant immunity from prosecution for any underlying conduct that is discussed, or other matters that don‚Äôt come up in testimony,‚Äù explain Adam Entous and Ellen Nakashima for the Washington Post. WHITE HOUSE OFFICIALS GAVE NUNES INTEL ‚Äî Three senior White House officials, including a top lawyer for the National Security Council and a former House Intel aide, helped facilitate the sharing of intelligence reports with House Intel Chairman Devin Nunes about Trump associates' communications, reports the New York Times and the Washington Post. ALRIGHT Y‚ÄôALL, FRIDAY. Welcome to March 31 and thanks for reading POLITICO‚Äôs Huddle, the play-by-play guide to all things Capitol Hill. Do yourself a favor and click through these adorable puppy engagement photos (yes, you read that right): http://bit.ly/2nEoDoS (h/t Kyle Cheney) THURSDAY‚ÄôS MOST CLICKED: Burgess and Seung Min‚Äôs write up on the Senate‚Äôs potential filibuster change was the winner. THIS IS FINE, EVERYTHING IS FINE ‚Äî It was hard to keep track of which Republican was attacking whom as GOP infighting exploded into the open Thursday, drowning out any last ditch efforts to salvage their Obamacare repeal before heading home for the weekend. Trump went after Freedom Caucus leaders Mark Meadows, Jim Jordan and Raul Labrador specifically over the repeal collapse and also more generally threatened to primary members of the caucus on Twitter. ** A message from USP: How do you ensure drug quality in a global economy? USP works with experts in science and health to develop independent, transparent quality standards for medicine. USP: Helping protect lives by safeguarding the quality of medicines for Americans. Learn more at http://qualitydrugstandards.org/ ** Not to be outdone, HFC member Justin Amash and Rep. Thomas Massie used their Twitter accounts to take on the president. And GOP Sen. Bob Corker even sniped at Speaker Ryan for encouraging Trump not to work with Democrats. ‚ÄúThe crossfire left a sour taste for lawmakers as they left town for the weekend without resolving any of the differences that ruptured health care deliberations the week before,‚Äù Kyle and Rachael report. More: http://politi.co/2oFb5Hk So how‚Äôs that Obamacare repeal going? ‚ÄúThe Tuesday Group will never meet with the Freedom Caucus. Capital N-E-V-E-R,‚Äù said Rep. Chris Collins (R-N.Y.), a member of the centrist group and Trump ally. Rachael, Kyle and Jen Hbaerkorn with the story: http://politi.co/2nROPNq Watch yourself: Rep. Mark Sanford was threatened with a primary challenge from the White House during last week‚Äôs repeal fiasco, he told the Post and Courier‚Äôs Emma Dumain. "'The president asked me to look you square in the eyes and to say that he hoped that you voted ‚Äòno‚Äô on this bill so he could run (a primary challenger) against you in 2018,'" Sanford said OMB Director Mick Mulvaney, a co-founder of the Freedom Caucus and former fellow member of the S.C. delegation, told him. More: http://bit.ly/2noVzPX RED STATE DEMS BACK GORSUCH ‚Äî Sens. Joe Manchin and Heidi Heitkamp became the first Democrats to publicly back Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch on Thursday. The support from the two red-state Democrats isn‚Äôt enough to stave off an all-but-guaranteed filibuster next week. But their endorsement could give other Democrats political cover to vote for Trump‚Äôs nominee. Now, some Senate Democrats are complaining Gorsuch is declining to meet with them, Elana and Seung Min report. Coming to a screen near you: The conservative Judicial Crisis Network followed Heitkamp and Manchin‚Äôs announcement by rolling out a $1 million ad buy aimed at pressuring the remaining Democratic fence-sitters: Sens. Michael Bennet, Joe Donnelly, Jon Tester, and Claire McCaskill. http://politi.co/2oFUoMe McCaskill‚Äôs no-win situation: McCaskill has stopped talking publicly about the battle to confirm Gorsuch. But behind closed doors, she said she is mortified about where the Senate is headed if Gorsuch is blocked and GOP leaders change the filibuster rules, Burgess reports. "I am very comfortable voting against [Gorsuch], but I‚Äôm very uncomfortable being part of a strategy that‚Äôs going to open up the Supreme Court to a complete change,‚Äù McCaskill said at a Missouri fundraiser, in audio first obtained by the Kansas City Star. More: http://politi.co/2oFYZ0V -The Missouri GOP party released the full audio from her fundraiser: http://bit.ly/2oFWTOq. Nuggets from the audio: McCaskill predicts GOP Rep. Ann Wagner will run against her and guesses the Senate race could cost more than $200 million, Burgess reports. A LITTLE HELP FROM MY FRIENDS ‚Äî Republican leaders summoned Sen. Johnny Isakson to the Capitol Thursday ‚Äì he‚Äôs been out for weeks recovering from surgery ‚Äî to help swing a tied vote targeting funding for Planned Parenthood. Vice President Mike Pence also had to come to the Hill to break the tie. More from Seung Min and Brianna Ehley: http://politi.co/2oEIVfF Johnny‚Äôs back: Isakson said that he‚Äôd likely be back again next week for the epic fight over the Supreme Court (‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt bet against it,‚Äù he said with a grin) but he faces a long road to recovery. The genial Georgian seemed in high spirits on Thursday but put it bluntly when asked how long his road to recovery is after two back surgeries: ‚ÄúI have eight more weeks of physical therapy,‚Äù he said. GEORGIA ON MY MIND ‚Äî Republicans are getting nervous that a crowded GOP field could hand Democrats an unexpected win in Georgia‚Äôs 6th District, the seat previously held by HHS Secretary Tom Price. ‚ÄúWe know that Ossoff is real,‚Äù NRCC chairman Steve Stivers told Elena Schneider. More on what the House GOP's campaign arm is doing to ensure the district doesn't flip to Democrats: http://politi.co/2noV1tk BUDDIES WITH A BIG JOB ‚Äî Senate Intel leaders Richard Burr and Mark Warner know they have a monumentally important task in front of them: Get to the bottom of Russia‚Äôs involvement in the election and whether Trump knew anything about it. But it also helps that they are long-time friends, facilitated by former Sen. Saxby Chambliss. Warner, a multimillionaire, ‚Äúregularly ribs Burr for wearing Kirkland Signature shirts purchased at Costco, and they sometimes travel together,‚Äù Paul Kane writes. The two also declined to support each other‚Äôs Senate opponents in recent years. Much more from the Washington Post: http://wapo.st/2nE5i7f WELCOME TO THE WORLD ‚Äî Shea Snider Miller, comms director for Rep. Mike Rogers (R-Ala.) and president of the Republican Communications Association, and Ben Miller, VP of production at Convergence Media and a Jim Sensenbrenner, GenOpp, and FP1 Strategies alum, have welcomed Bishop Collins Miller. Pic from his baptism on Sunday in Alabama: http://bit.ly/2oGn4Ey TODAY IN CONGRESS ‚Äî The House and Senate are out. Phew. AROUND THE HILL ‚Äî Who‚Äôs hosting the off-the-record happy hour today? I‚Äôll bring snacks. THURSDAY‚ÄôS TRIVIA WINNER ‚Äî Peter Roff was the first to guess that John F. Kennedy wrote the Encyclopedia Britannica entry on Oliver Ellsworth, a senator from Connecticut and third chief justice. TODAY‚ÄôS TRIVIA ‚Äî Tyler Law with today‚Äôs question: How many people have served as a city council member, mayor, governor and senator and who are they? The first person to correctly answer gets a shout out in Monday‚Äôs Huddle. And don‚Äôt forget, send suggestions for trivia questions my way: hcaygle@politico.com GET HUDDLE emailed to your phone each morning. ** A message from USP: How do you ensure drug quality in a global economy? USP works with experts in science and health to develop independent, transparent quality standards for medicine. From aspirin to zolpidem, our quality standards help ensure products are safe and reliable. We are an essential piece of the safety net that ensures quality standards are met, in order to improve public health in the United States and around the world. USP: Helping protect lives by safeguarding the quality of medicines for Americans. Learn more at http://qualitydrugstandards.org/ ** ¬´ View Archives This story tagged under: Congress Most Read FBI releases never-before-seen photos from 9/11 Pentagon attack The nation‚Äôs cartoonists on the week in politics Chaffetz: ‚ÄòVery mysterious‚Äô why Flynn suddenly wants immunity Democrats aim to take out Cruz in 2018 Democrats in Trump territory in no mood to deal Schiff slams White House after reviewing controversial intelligence No Obamacare cease-fire in red states Liberals taste victory no matter Gorsuch outcome Trump: Flynn should seek immunity in Russia probe ‚Äòwitch hunt‚Äô Trump suffers month of rough polling Huddle -
